Efficient lean-burn gasoline engines cannot employ traditional three-way catalysts (TWCs) to control NOX emissions due to excess oxygen. Passive selective catalytic reduction (pSCR) is a process designed to control NOx by generating NH3 over the TWC during fuel-rich operation, storing it on a downstream SCR, and then converting NOx during fuel-lean operation. This work is focused on studying sulfur effects on this promising strategy. Two hydrothermally-aged commercial catalysts were studied for their effectiveness in the presence of SO2: a Pd-based TWC and a TWC with NOX storage. The sulfated samples were evaluated in a flow reactor under pSCR conditions and with targeted reactions. SO2 inhibited the water gas shift and steam reforming reactions, decreasing (but not eliminating) NH3 production; however, initial activity is recoverable after a simple thermal treatment at 650 °C. This work will prove valuable in understanding, mitigating, and even reversing the effects of SO2 inhibition on real pSCR systems. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Passive SCR Lean-burn gasoline emissions control Sulfur Ammonia (NH3) Generation Three-way catalysts (TWC) 1 Introduction Lean burn gasoline engines operate with an increased air-fuel ratio compared to traditional stoichiometrically operated engines, which allows up to 15 % reduced fuel consumption [1–3]. However, due to the excess oxygen in the exhaust, the NOX emissions cannot be reduced with traditional three-way catalyst (TWC) exhaust treatment systems and are a concern for their implementation [4,5]. Passive SCR (pSCR) is an exhaust treatment system intended to reduce NOX in this situation [6,7]. In a pSCR system, the engine is periodically operated under slightly fuel rich conditions (λ = 0.90–0.99). Operating with excess fuel provides the catalyst with additional reductants, such as CO, H2, and hydrocarbons, that reduce the NOX in the exhaust to NH3 during rich operation. This NH3 is then stored on a down-stream SCR catalyst where it is utilized for NOX SCR during lean operation. Because the production of NH3 over a TWC during rich operation is one of the primary drivers of this system, it is important to understand it. Research has long shown that NH3 generation from inlet NOX was possible over TWCs, and some have shown that nearly 100 % selectivity to NH3 from inlet NOX can be achieved at normal operating temperatures with traditional TWC materials [8–10]. Furthermore, research implementing both TWC and SCR catalysts in series on a real engine system has shown that the system is viable, providing fuel efficiency benefits up to 11 %, while maintaining > 99 % NOX conversion [11,12]. However, for pSCR to become commercially viable, the system must continue to perform after physical and chemical degradation. Physical degradation is caused by the harsh hydrothermal conditions in the exhaust stream where temperatures can exceed 900 °C, leading to extensive catalyst sintering and loss of activity. These effects were evaluated in previous work [13]. In that work, it was found that hydrothermal aging did lead to significant degradation of the materials used, but the degradation did not have a strong effect on the production of NH3. Chemical degradation is caused by the presence of species in the exhaust that either bind strongly to the catalyst, blocking sites, or react directly with the catalyst, changing it into a less active material. Phosphorus and sulfur are some of the most prevalent species in automotive exhausts that lead to significant chemical degradation in automotive catalysts [14–17]. The impacts of sulfur have become even more important as TWCs have shifted towards Pd as the primary platinum group metal (PGM) and elements such as Ce and Ba have become more common. These formulations have shown higher susceptibility to sulfur poisoning than older Pt-based TWCs [18–20]. Ce is used as a catalyst support, promoter, and oxygen storage component in TWC formulations. Poisoning of Ce by sulfur has been shown to increase CO light-off significantly in Pd/CeO2/Al2O3 catalysts, as well as reduce their oxygen storage capacity (OSC) [21–23]. The effect of sulfur on Ce was also examined in a study utilizing CoOX/CeO2 catalysts which showed that the deposition of stable sulfites and sulfates interrupted the Ce3+ to Ce4+ redox cycle thereby inhibiting oxygen mobility [24]. Ba is used primarily as a NOX storage component (NSC) in automotive catalysts [25–27]. Barium sulfates have shown even greater stability than cerium sulfates, and the inhibition of barium due to sulfur is a large concern, particularly in NOX storage and reduction (NSR) catalysts [28–30]. While the subject of sulfur poisoning on TWCs has received extensive attention in previous literature, its relevance to NH3 generation, rich operation, and pSCR has not been thoroughly investigated. In this work, we examine the effects of realistic levels of SO2 on two hydrothermally aged, commercially formulated TWCs for the purposes of implementation into a pSCR system. This is accomplished through exposure to synthetic exhaust mixtures as well as conditions designed to isolate individual reactions. The synthetic exhaust evaluations are conducted before sulfation, after sulfation, and after desulfation of the catalyst samples. Exhaust is simulated under two different engine-relevant operating conditions, and the activity of isolated reactions is evaluated after sulfation and after desulfation of the catalyst samples. The isolated reactions include the production of NH3 using the three individual reductants (H2, CO, C3H8) and the production of H2 from both CO and C3H8 through the water gas shift (WGS) and steam reformation reactions. The results from the isolated reactions are then used to deconvolute the synthetic exhaust results to determine which reactive pathways are the cause for changes seen in the synthetic exhaust, leading to a better understanding of the operational concerns resulting from the presence of SO2 in a pSCR system. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts studied Two commercially formulated catalysts were studied as shown in Table 1. The first, designated Pd-TWC, is from the front portion of a dual-zone TWC used in a 2009 PZEV (Partial Zero Emissions Vehicle) Chevrolet Malibu. It contains Pd as the only active PGM on the surface, but also contains very low loadings of various promoters, including Ce and Ba. The second catalyst is a NOX storage TWC (NS-TWC) formulation provided by Umicore. The NS-TWC, in contrast to the Pd-TWC, contains a mixture of Pt, Pd and a small amount of Rh, as well as significant amounts of OSC and NSC. These catalysts were chosen based on their high performance in previous work [31]. In that work, the Pd-TWC showed the best projected fuel efficiency at high temperatures, while the NS-TWC showed the best projected fuel efficiency at low temperatures due to the NSC. Catalyst samples were aged using a four-mode hydrothermal aging procedure at 900 °C. This aging procedure consists of a long stoichiometric exposure for 330 s, followed by a short reducing exposure of 10 s, a short stoichiometric exposure of 10 s, and a lean exposure of 10 s as shown in Table 2. Each step has 2 % CO, 10 % H2O, 10 % CO2, and balance N2. The stoichiometric exposure has 1 % O2, the rich exposure has no O2, and the lean exposure has 10 % O2. The results of this aging are outlined in a previous report [13]. 2.2 Reactor Apparatus The apparatus used in these experiments controls gas flow through thirteen separate MKS 1479A Mass-Flow controllers. Water is introduced to the reactant stream using an Eldex Optos HPLC Pump. Switching between the lean phase and rich phase is controlled using a Valco A4UWE 1/8 in. switching valve, which allows for switching times of 0.2–0.5 s. The catalyst is housed in a 25 mm outer diameter quartz tube heated by a Thermo Scientific Lindberg/Blue M TF55035C tube furnace. The catalyst itself is not in the heated zone of the furnace, but rather at the end, where it is well insulated. Omega K-type 0.5 mm thermocouples are used to monitor the temperature of the gas upstream of the catalyst as well as the temperature gradient across the catalyst. The reactor effluent is monitored using both an MKS Multigas 2030HS Gas-Phase FTIR and a Pfeifer Vacuum PrismaPlus mass spectrometer. 2.3 Synthetic exhaust evaluation The conditions for lean and rich gas flows are shown in Table 3 for the two different operating conditions: fixed load and load step. The concentrations were determined through sampling of the exhaust from a lean engine setup shown in previous work [11]. Fixed load simulates pSCR operation when the engine is under a constant load and there is not significant acceleration or deceleration, such as highway driving. Under lean conditions, there is significantly more air introduced for the same amount of fuel, resulting in a higher space velocity under lean conditions than rich conditions. The NOx concentration is lower under lean conditions due to dilution by excess air. However, since the flow rate is higher, the NOX flux is the same under lean and rich conditions, which leads to roughly the same amount of time spent operating rich and lean. During typical automotive operation, the load requirements of the engine vary, and when the engine is under heavy load, NOX production is increased. This increased NOX can be used to opportunistically produce more NH3 by running rich during periods of high loads. This process is simulated by the load step condition. In contrast to fixed load, load step uses higher space velocity and higher NOx concentration in the rich phase. This leads to reduced rich operating times and better projected fuel efficiency benefits when compared to fixed load. Throughout the synthetic exhaust experiments, the catalysts undergo continuous lean/rich cycling controlled through a LabVIEW program. The program monitors the outlet NOX and NH3 concentrations to determine when to switch phases. When the integrated outlet NOX in the lean phase reaches a threshold value, the system switches to rich operation. Then, once the integrated outlet NH3 in the rich phase reaches the same threshold, the system switches back to lean. The threshold value was calculated to utilize 25 % of the NH3 storage capacity of a commercial Cu-exchanged SCR catalyst. The feedback control based on the monitoring of NOX breakthrough and NH3 breakthrough automatically adjusts the lean and rich operating times, allowing for an estimate of the fuel penalty associated with implementation of a passive SCR system. Prior to evaluations, the catalyst is pretreated at a furnace temperature of 650 °C and a λ of 0.95 for 30 min to establish a consistent starting state. The sample is then cooled to 350 °C, where it is evaluated under cycling conditions for 1 h. Next, it is heated in 50 °C increments from 350° to 650°C and evaluated under cycling conditions for 1 h at each temperature. This set of experiments provides the baseline clean activity of the catalyst sample. Once the catalyst has been evaluated at 650 °C, it is again pretreated, cooled to 350 °C, and exposed to 2 ppm SO2 for 12.5 h under cycling conditions. The flow of SO2 is then stopped and the catalyst is again evaluated between 350 and 650 °C to determine the cycling activity of the sulfated catalyst. Note that exposure to SO2 at 350 °C for 12.5 h is a somewhat extreme poisoning event as TWC operating temperatures are typically much higher than this during normal drive cycle operating conditions. It is anticipated that higher temperature operation would release much of the sulfur from the catalyst surface. To test this theory, the system is cycled between the lean and rich conditions for 3 h at 650 °C to desulfate the catalyst. After a final pretreatment, the catalyst temperature is dropped, and its activity is once again measured between 350 and 650 °C to determine the effectiveness of desulfation. This procedure is repeated for both fixed load and load step operating conditions over the Pd-TWC and NS-TWC samples. Since sulfation primarily impacts TWC operation under rich conditions, several summary quantities were calculated from the rich portions of the synthetic exhaust experiments. The NH3 yield and NOX conversion were both calculated based on the rich phase NOX supplied to the catalyst. Additionally, the average rich phase concentration of N2O, H2, CO, and C3H8 were calculated. 2.4 Isolated reaction evaluation After desulfation, the catalyst samples used in the synthetic exhaust experiments are used for the evaluation of the activity of isolated reactions. Table 4 shows the conditions used to evaluate the activity of individual reactions over both the Pd-TWC and the NS-TWC. These experiments are conducted with a constant space velocity of 27,000 hr−1, with the only change between the lean and rich conditions being the introduction of 10 % O2 to the lean phase (there is no O2 in the rich phase). This allows for the reactions that produce NH3 and H2 to dominate in the rich phase, while the oxidation reactions dominate in the lean phase. The evaluation of isolated reactions is similar to the evaluation of synthetic exhaust. First, the catalyst is pretreated at 650 °C under rich NO + H2 + H2O exposure for 30 min to reduce the catalyst. The sample is cooled to 350 °C, where it is evaluated under cycling conditions for 1 h for each reaction condition shown in Table 3. Next, it is heated in 100 °C increments from 350° to 650°C, and each reaction is evaluated under cycling conditions for 1 h at each temperature. This provides the desulfated activity of the catalyst sample. Once the catalyst has been evaluated at 650 °C, it is again pretreated, cooled to 350 °C, and exposed to 2 ppm SO2 for 12.5 h under cycling NO + H2 + H2O conditions. The flow of SO2 is then stopped, and the catalyst is again evaluated between 350 and 650 °C to determine the sulfated catalyst activity. Several quantities were calculated from the isolated reaction experiments. The H2 yield was calculated based on the total reductant supplied to the catalyst during the rich phase. NH3 yields for the isolated reactions were calculated based on NOX supplied to the catalyst during rich operation. 3 Results and discussion The effects of sulfur poisoning on TWC reactivity are diverse, resulting in changes in the measured concentrations of several exhaust components. Many of these gases are essential for pSCR operation, both for the production of NH3 and for meeting emissions regulations. The main gases monitored during these experiments fall into two categories: nitrogen species and reductants. The nitrogen species monitored are NH3, NOX, and N2O, while the reductants measured are H2, CO, and C3H8. Monitoring the nitrogen species allows us to see the products of NOX reduction, and changes in those nitrogen species can elucidate the changes in catalyst surface chemistry due to sulfation. The reductants, and their relative concentrations, can help elucidate changes in the activity of secondary reactions, such as WGS and steam reformation, which can have strong effects on the production of NH3 from NOX. 3.1 Inhibition during sulfation The catalyst effluent concentrations were monitored continuously during sulfation at 350 °C. Fig. 1a shows time series data during the first 30 min of sulfation under fixed load conditions for both the Pd-TWC and the NS-TWC. It can be seen from this data that, during the rich phase, there is significant CO breakthrough and NH3 production, while NOX and C3H8 show nearly complete conversion. Conversely, during the lean phase, there is no NH3 production or CO breakthrough, while the NOX and C3H8 breakthrough is much higher. During the exposure to SO2, the most immediate effect is the decrease in outlet NH3 and increase in outlet CO in the rich phase. During this time, there is not a significant amount of either C3H8 or NOX in the rich phase. This complete conversion of C3H8 during the rich phase is consistent with our prior research [13]. The activity then continues to drop at a much slower pace as the sulfation continues as shown in Fig. 1b. However, the NS-TWC shows a more continuous inhibition throughout the sulfation process. This is likely due to the high loading of barium and cerium, which allows for a larger concentration of stable sulfur species to be formed. This causes the catalyst to continue being inhibited as the barium and cerium continue to store sulfur in the form of sulfate species [20,32]. During sulfation, rich phase NOX conversion decreases across both catalysts and for both conditions, but it stays above 95 %. On the Pd-TWC, the conversion decreases from 100 % to 95–98 % depending on the reactive condition. There is very little overall change in the NOX emissions on the NS-TWC; however, the feedback-controlled timing of the lean and rich phases changes, which correlates with overall fuel efficiency. While the rich phase conversion of C3H8 is close to 100 % for both the clean Pd-TWC and the clean NS-TWC, it drops to roughly 90 % for each catalyst and operating condition over the course of the sulfation. Inhibition of rich phase C3H8 conversion only occurs after 2 h for fixed load conditions but is apparent in the first 30 min of the load step exposure for both catalyst samples. This is likely due to the higher space velocity in the load step rich phase. 3.2 Synthetic exhaust evaluation before sulfation, after sulfation, and after desulfation 3.2.1 Evaluation of Nitrogen Species The NH3 production/yield for each catalyst, operating condition, and sulfation state is shown in Fig. 2a. Sulfation has a notable negative effect on the production of NH3 for both catalysts and under both operating conditions. This inhibition is observed at all temperatures. to some extent but is strongest between 450 and 550 °C where NH3 production decreases by 25–45 %. Because the process of NH3 production in synthetic exhaust is complex, it is not possible to determine the reactive pathways that lead to this inhibition from this data alone (further studies to elucidate this are covered in the next section). Despite the inhibition, the NH3 yield is higher than 30 % under all circumstances and the clean catalyst activity was recovered through regeneration via lean/rich cycling at 650 °C for 3 h. This shows that, while sulfur inhibition is a concern, NH3 can still be produced in its presence, and the inhibition can be reversed through elevated temperature operation of a pSCR system. The inhibition of NH3 production due to sulfation means the system requires longer rich operation to produce enough NH3 for NOx conversion during subsequent lean phases. Because of the decreased NH3 production at elevated temperatures and under sulfated conditions, the requisite NH3 can take up to 5 min to produce, compared to < 2.5 min for the lower temperature clean conditions. The increase in rich phase operating time introduces two issues for the implementation of pSCR. First, operating rich for a longer period leads to decreased fuel efficiency since excess fuel is burned to generate rich exhaust conditions. Second, it will likely lead to increased CO emissions, since CO is difficult to fully eliminate while running rich. While NOX emissions during lean operation cannot be controlled over a TWC, the conversion during rich operation is an important consideration for pSCR operation because NOX SCR functions through a redox cycle, which requires oxygen to be present [33–35]. The rich phase NOX conversion under each synthetic exhaust operating condition is shown in Fig. 2b. Despite the strong inhibition of NH3 production from sulfation, the rich phase NOX conversion remains high for the Pd-TWC, only showing significant inhibition under load step operation above 450 °C. This is due to the increased NOX concentration and space velocity/flowrate under load step operation, which leads to NOX breakthrough in the rich phase. On the Pd-TWC, in the worst-case high temperature load step operation on a sulfated catalyst, the conversion of NOX is maintained above 90 %. In contrast, the production of NH3 drops by > 20 % under intermediate temperatures. This indicates that, while the specific reaction routes leading to the production of NH3 are inhibited by sulfation, the rich phase conversion of NOX is not as strongly affected. In contrast to the Pd-TWC, the NS-TWC shows lower rich phase NOX conversion both before and after sulfation. Prior to sulfation, the NS-TWC shows a significant amount of NOx slip in the rich phase; however, this slip is due exclusively to the release of stored NOX during the transition from lean to rich operation. Sulfation has two distinct effects on the rich phase breakthrough of NOX on the NS-TWC: it inhibits the NOX storage during the lean phase and the NOX reduction during the rich phase. The two effects of sulfation on rich phase NOX conversion over the NS-TWC are shown in Fig. 3, which compares the rich phase of both fixed load and load step before and after sulfation on the NS-TWC at 500 °C, where the NOX conversion is at its lowest. The inhibition of the NOX storage leads to less NOX released during the transition from lean to rich, as evidenced by the smaller NO spikes during the first ~10 s of the rich phase. This has a positive effect on the overall rich phase NOX conversion, which can be seen at low temperatures in Fig. 2b. However, as the rich phase continues, a clear NOX breakthrough is present on the sulfated catalyst while the clean catalyst shows no breakthrough. This is likely due to the propensity for sulfur to form a sulfide with the platinum group metals during rich operation, and to form sulfates on metal oxides during lean operation [36]. Thus, during the transition, these sulfates could be transitioning to the PGM surface in the form of sulfides. Because the NS-TWC likely stores a significant amount of sulfur from the NSC and OSC loading, there is more sulfur being trapped by the catalyst, which results in stronger inhibition and more NOx slip during the rich phase when compared to the Pd-TWC. Despite the inhibition after sulfur exposure, the activity for NOX conversion was fully recovered through the desulfation procedure that exposed the catalyst to lean/rich cycling at 650 °C. The final nitrogen species being monitored is N2O, which is a potent greenhouse gas with a global warming potential roughly 300 times higher than CO2 over a 100 year period [37]. Previous research on the effects of sulfation on TWC operation has suggested that sulfur exposure could increase N2O production and decrease NH3 production during rich operation [10,38,39]. The changes in average rich phase N2O production for both the Pd-TWC and NS-TWC are shown in Fig. 4a. For the clean evaluations, very little N2O production is observed across both catalysts and both operating conditions. After sulfation, a significant increase in N2O production is observed when operating under load step conditions for both catalysts; it is especially high on the NS-TWC. Under fixed load conditions, the average N2O production in the rich phase remains below 2 ppm for the Pd-TWC and under 10 ppm for the NS-TWC. The increase during load step operation is likely due to the higher rich phase space velocity and inlet NO concentration. However, the increase in N2O does not account for the decrease in NH3 production seen under the same. conditions, indicating that the decreased NH3 production results in additional N2 formation, rather than N2O. As with NH3 yield and NOx conversion, the desulfation procedure results in a return to the clean level of catalyst activity. Fig. 4b shows the time series data for N2O during the rich phase under load step conditions over the Pd-TWC and the NS-TWC. This data further illustrates the multiple stages of transition within the rich phase, which is also seen in the NOX concentrations. On the clean catalyst samples, there is an initial peak in N2O formation, followed by a slightly longer N2O production. These peaks are the result of stored NOX being only partially reduced due to insufficient reductant concentrations during the transition from lean to rich. Peaks occurring at the same time corresponding to the release of NOX can be seen in Fig. 3. This is further evidenced by the relative intensity of this N2O production, with the NS-TWC showing significantly higher production due to higher NSC. After sulfation, the N2O production during the lean-to-rich transition is still present, but there is a second transition over a longer timeframe that produces significantly more N2O. This longer transition matches the breakthrough of NOX in the rich phase, shown in Fig. 3, indicating that it is likely also the result of sulfur migration from the Ba and Ce to form sulfides on the PGM components. On the sulfated NS-TWC, as the operating temperature increases, the rate of the transition increases, but the steady state production of N2O also decreases. This results in a maximum N2O concentration around 450–500 °C. 3.2.2 Evaluation of reductants While monitoring the nitrogen species provides details on how the inlet NOX is reduced on the catalysts, there is also significant information that can be gained by observing the relative concentration of the various reductants present in the synthetic exhaust. The levels of these. reductants have been shown to have a large effect on the production of NH3 during rich operation [40–42]. The concentration of CO in the rich phase for each catalyst, operating condition, and sulfation condition are shown in Fig. 5a. While CO is a toxic gas that must be minimized in the tailpipe exhaust, the presence of CO during NOX reduction has been shown to have a large benefit to the production of NH3 over TWCs, particularly when combined with H2 [8]. In the synthetic exhaust experiments, CO is fully converted during lean operation, regardless of sulfation level. However, under rich operating conditions, the concentration of CO increases after sulfur exposure throughout the temperature range for each catalyst and operating condition. There are two potential causes for the overall inhibition seen here. First, it could be due to a change in the catalysts’ activity for the WGS reaction, which previous literature has shown to be strongly inhibited by the presence of sulfur [43]. Second, CO oxidation could be inhibited by sulfation, which has been shown at lower temperatures and under rich conditions [17,44]. This increase exacerbates one of the significant remaining challenges associated with pSCR, as CO is a regulated emission that must be minimized. However, as with the N-containing species, the conversion of CO is recovered through the desulfation procedure during operation at 650 °C. Fig. 5b shows the average rich phase H2 concentration downstream of the catalyst. High H2 concentrations are beneficial because H2 and its production through WGS have both been shown to promote the production of NH3 on TWCs [40]. During lean operation, H2 is fully converted, while a significant amount remains during rich operation. However, contrary to CO, the rich phase H2 decreases after sulfation. This decrease closely mirrors the CO increase observed throughout the temperature range for each catalyst and reactive condition. This indicates that an inhibition in the WGS reaction is likely a large contributor to the concentration changes seen in these two species. Furthermore, the decrease in H2 concentration is likely a contributor to the overall decrease in NH3 production, as the reduction of NO with H2 has been shown to be a highly active pathway for NH3 production. As with all previous reactions, the initial H2 production activity was recovered after desulfation. Fig. 5c shows the average outlet concentration of C3H8 in the rich phase for each catalyst, operating condition, and sulfation state. Prior to sulfation, there is minimal C3H8 breakthrough in the rich phase. This is attributed to the catalysts’ high activity for the steam reforming of C3H8 under these conditions. However, after sulfation, the rich phase C3H8 in the effluent stream increases for both catalysts and both operating conditions. This is more notable on the NS-TWC than the Pd-TWC. The Pd-TWC shows less than 70 ppm average rich phase C3H8 regardless of operation temperature or condition. The NS-TWC shows significant breakthrough above 400 °C, with a maximum at 500–550 °C depending on the operating condition. However, as with the other species observed, desulfation restores the original behavior. Fig. 6 shows the breakthrough of C3H8 as a function of time for the Pd-TWC under fixed load conditions at 350 °C for both the clean and sulfated conditions. For the clean catalyst, C3H8 is almost entirely eliminated in the rich phase, while showing significant breakthrough in the lean phase. After sulfation, there is a strong increase in the C3H8 in the rich phase, while the lean phase C3H8 levels are not significantly affected. While steam reforming contributes to the conversion of C3H8 in the rich phase, the direct oxidation of C3H8 is the primary reaction in the lean phase. Thus, it is possible that the sulfur is primarily inhibiting the steam reformation reaction, rather than C3H8 oxidation. Furthermore, considering this in conjunction with the results in Fig. 5c, the inhibition of steam reforming is likely more significant on the NS-TWC compared to the Pd-TWC. It is also worth noting that the increased C3H8 in the rich phase during the sulfated evaluation coincides with increased N2O production and decreased NOX conversion. This suggests that the inhibition of the steam reforming reaction is attributed to the same long-term transition seen in the transient NOX and N2O results shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4b. 3.3 Isolated reactions after sulfation and after desulfation To test the theories proposed above, additional lean-rich cycling experiments were conducted with simplified gas mixtures to isolate specific reactions. NH3 production from specific reductants, WGS, and steam reforming reactions were evaluated to measure the impact of sulfation. The water gas shift and steam reforming reactions can be very important for the production of NH3 because they provide a mechanism to produce H2 from other reductants. In addition to these reactions, an additional reaction has been proposed for the production of NH3 when CO is used as a reductant. This mechanism requires the formation and subsequent hydrolysis of isocyanate (NCO-) species on the surface [42,45]. 3.3.1 Production of NH3 from NO, H2, and H2O The production of NH3 from NO, H2, and H2O for both catalysts is shown in Fig. 7. Under these conditions, both catalysts maintain high activity for NH3 production, with rich phase NH3 yields between 80 % and 100 % throughout the temperature range, with minimal impact from sulfur exposure. The NS-TWC shows slightly better NH3 yield at low temperature and the Pd-TWC shows slightly better NH3 yield at elevated temperatures, which matches with the prior synthetic exhaust mixture results. These results suggest that sulfur does not inhibit the production of NH3 from NO and H2, and therefore this is not the primary mechanism for the changes in NH3 yield observed in the synthetic exhaust studies in Fig. 2a. 3.3.2 Production of NH3 and H2 from NO, CO, and H2O Fig. 8 shows NH3 production while feeding NO, CO, and H2O for both the Pd-TWC and the NS-TWC. Much like NH3 production from H2, the reaction shows high activity before sulfation. The NS-TWC shows better low temperature yield, while both catalysts show similar high temperature yields that are somewhat less than observed with H2 as the reductant. However, in this case, there is a significant change in activity after sulfation. This could be due to the inhibition of the WGS reaction, which would decrease the amount of H2 available for the reduction of NO to NH3, and has been shown in previous literature to be strongly inhibited by sulfation [43]. Another possibility is that the hydrolysis of isocyanates is impacted, which has been proposed as an alternate means of production for NH3 [42]. In contrast to the direct reduction of NO with H2 to for NH3, the hydrolysis of isocyanates would not require the production of molecular H2 to be effective. To further investigate the inhibition of the different reaction pathways from sulfation, the production of H2 from the WGS reaction was examined. Fig. 8b shows the rich phase production of H2 from the WGS reaction on both the Pd-TWC and the NS-TWC with and without NO in the stream. At 350 °C, neither catalyst is very active for H2 production, showing 5–15 % yield. Despite this low H2 production, both catalysts have high NH3 yields at these temperatures, as seen in Fig. 8a. If molecular H2 is a necessary intermediate in the production of NH3, then achieving the 90–100 % yield seen in those experiments would require the consumption of between 0.08 % and 0.15 % H2, depending on the proportion of the following two reactions, which have been shown to be active for NH3 production [8]. (3) NO+2·5 H2↔H2O+NH3 (4) NO+CO+1·5 H2↔CO2+NH3 However, when NO is added to the reactive stream at 350 °C, this significant decrease (0.08 – 0.15 %) in H2 yield is not observed. This suggests that the above reactions are not the only mechanism by which the NH3 is produced and that molecular H2 is not a necessary intermediate in the production of NH3 from NO + CO + H2O during this low temperature operation. A potential explanation is that some of the NH3 is formed from the alternate pathway of hydrolysis of isocyanate species at 350 °C. After sulfation, there is a significant decrease in H2 production both with and without NO in the reactive stream at temperatures above 350 °C. These results confirm that the WGS reaction is being heavily inhibited by sulfation. Furthermore, this is likely one of the causes of the inhibition seen in Fig. 8a, particularly at elevated temperatures. However, after sulfation, the H2 production at 350 °C is not inhibited, even though NH3 production decreases, as seen in Fig. 8a. This indicates that the inhibition route at this temperature is unlikely to be the production of H2 and is likely due to a change in either the formation or the hydrolysis of isocyanate species on the surface. 3.3.3 Production of NH3 and H2 from NO, C3H8, and H2O The production of NH3 from C3H8, NO, and H2O is shown in Fig. 9a. On the Pd-TWC, there are only minor changes in NH3 production after sulfation. In contrast, the inhibition over the NS-TWC is stronger and there is a consistent inhibition throughout the temperature range. Fig. 9b shows the propane slip for both the Pd-TWC and the NS-TWC when exposing the catalyst to C3H8 and H2O. On the Pd-TWC, the effects of sulfation are negligible, and C3H8 only shows significant slip at 350 °C both before and after sulfation. In contrast, the NS-TWC shows significant C3H8 breakthrough at 650 °C after sulfation. The H2 production from C3H8 and H2O with and without NO is shown in Fig. 10. Unlike the NH3 production, there is a clear inhibition in H2 production over the Pd-TWC throughout the temperature range. In contrast, on the NS-TWC, the inhibition shows a much stronger reliance on temperature, with significant inhibition occurring at 550 and 650 °C. This high temperature inhibition corresponds to the decreased C3H8 conversion seen in Fig. 9b. 3.3.4 Carbon balance during reaction of C3H8 and H2O The deactivation trends in Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 are more complex than those seen in previous experiments because of the complexities involved in using C3H8 as a reductant. The process does not exclusively entail the reaction of H2O and C3H8 to form CO2 and H2, but rather, the C3H8 can be partially converted to C3H6, C2H6, CH4, or CO [46]. The quantities of these species can provide valuable insights into the inhibition caused by SO2 exposure for not only the steam reforming of C3H8, but also the steam reforming of other small hydrocarbons and the. elimination of CO through the water gas shift reaction. While no significant amount of C3H6 or C2H6 were detected during these experiments, significant amounts of CH4, CO, and CO2 were present. To better understand the intermediate reactions and how they change with sulfur exposure, Fig. 11 shows the breakdown of where the carbon species are going during the rich phase of the C3H8 isolated reaction experiments. Before sulfation, both catalysts only show significant production of CH4 at 450 °C. The CH4 seen in these evaluations is due to the partial conversion of C3H8 from the steam reforming reaction, rather than the hydrogenation of CO or CO2, confirmed by the lack of CH4 produced during CO + H2O exposure. Sulfation does not significantly change CH4 production on the Pd-TWC but does increase the CH4 at 450 °C on the NS-TWC. This is likely due to an inhibition of the steam reforming reactions on the NS-TWC, which prevents the catalyst. from further converting CH4 or creates conditions that favor its formation. In the case of CO, there is a significant increase in the production of CO after sulfation over the Pd-TWC, while the NS-TWC shows negligible inhibition in this regard. Furthermore, the increase in CO over the Pd-TWC accounts for the difference in H2 production. This leads to the conclusion that the changes in Pd-TWC H2 production seen in Fig. 10 are likely due primarily to an inhibition of the WGS reaction, rather than changes in steam reforming activity. In contrast, the NS-TWC does not show strongly increased CO production, indicating that the overall inhibition seen in both H2 and NH3 production is due primarily to an inhibition in the steam reforming reaction. This difference in deactivation pathways results in a stronger inhibition of NH3 production by the NS-TWC after sulfur exposure when C3H8 is used as a reductant. It was also observed that, in some experiments with C3H8 as the reductant, there was less total carbon in the catalyst effluent than was fed to the catalyst during rich operation. This indicates that there is likely a buildup of carbon species on the catalyst surface during rich operation, which is common during these types of steam reforming reactions [47]. However, for those same experiments, there was more total carbon in the catalyst effluent under the subsequent lean operation, indicating that the carbon species deposited on the catalyst were oxidized. Since the reactive conditions are transitioning between lean and rich conditions every 2 min, the carbon species are regularly removed from the catalyst surface, so the catalyst activity does not degrade during the evaluation experiments. Relating these isolated reaction experiments back to the synthetic exhaust experiments allows us to gain greater insight into the effects of individual reactions on the overall reactions taking place in automotive exhaust. A key point is that the reduction of NO to NH3 by H2 is unaffected by the sulfation procedure used here, but the production of NH3 in the synthetic exhaust decreases significantly by the same procedure. This indicates that the decrease in NH3 production in the synthetic exhaust experiments is not due to the direct reaction of NO and H2. Rather, it is due to the decrease in the production of NH3 and H2 when using CO and C3H8 as reductants. An inhibition was seen in both the WGS and steam reforming reactions, with the Pd-TWC showing stronger inhibition for the WGS reaction, and the NS-TWC showing stronger inhibition for the steam reforming reaction. Additionally, from the reaction of CO, NO, and H2O, it seems that the production of molecular H2 is not the only viable means of NH3 production. These results suggest that, particularly at lower temperatures, some of the catalyst activity can be attributed to the hydrolysis of isocyanates on the catalyst. 4 Conclusions Synthetic exhaust flow reactor experiments showed that sulfur exposure: • Significantly decreases NH3 yield for both TWC materials. • Reduces rich-phase NOx conversion at high temperatures for the Pd-TWC and across most of the temperature range for the NS-TWC. • Increases N2O production, particularly under load-step operating conditions. • Increases CO slip for both catalysts. • Decreases H2 production for both catalysts. Focused experiments aimed at isolating the effects of sulfur exposure on individual reaction pathways revealed the following: • Sulfur does not significantly inhibit formation of NH3 from NO + H2. • Sulfur does inhibit formation of NH3 when CO or C3H8 are used as reductant. • Sulfur inhibits WGS and steam reforming reactions. The extent of this inhibition is dependent on catalyst formulation. • Formation of NH3 from CO does not necessarily proceed through a WGS pathway to molecular H2. These effects were observed after extensive sulfur exposure and the inhibition was reversed by operating under standard passive SCR lean/rich cycles at 650 °C, with the desulfated catalyst showing near-identical activity to the clean evaluation. This work shows that, while sulfur is indeed an obstacle for the implementation of a passive SCR system, it is not an insurmountable one. By studying catalysts under both realistic and idealized conditions, the primary points of inhibition have been isolated. These can potentially be addressed in future work to better understand and implement passive SCR systems into lean gasoline engines. coredata.dc:description: Efficient lean-burn gasoline engines cannot employ traditional three-way catalysts (TWCs) to control NOX emissions due to excess oxygen. Passive selective catalytic reduction (pSCR) is a process designed to control NOx by generating NH3 over the TWC during fuel-rich operation, storing it on a downstream SCR, and then converting NOx during fuel-lean operation. This work is focused on studying sulfur effects on this promising strategy. Two hydrothermally-aged commercial catalysts were studied for their effectiveness in the presence of SO2: a Pd-based TWC and a TWC with NOX storage. The sulfated samples were evaluated in a flow reactor under pSCR conditions and with targeted reactions. SO2 inhibited the water gas shift and steam reforming reactions, decreasing (but not eliminating) NH3 production; however, initial activity is recoverable after a simple thermal treatment at 650 °C. This work will prove valuable in understanding, mitigating, and even reversing the effects of SO2 inhibition on real pSCR systems.
coredata.dc:title: The effects of SO2 exposure on three-way catalysts for passive SCR operation
